comment.author: 16967530@N03
comment._content: I am not sure but I think the term grafter refers not to hard work in the modern sense but to the grafting of fruit trees by inserting growing material from one tree into the cut rootstock of another. The rows of trees here suggests an orchard, the boy with a barrow in the background perhaps with tolls or materials and the man preparing a new rootstock. The woman is mysterious, what is she doing just sitting there? Looking closer she is holding a branch which is what will be grafted onto the rootstock.

comment.author: 7724352@N02
comment._content: Yes this would most definitely refer to the grafting of fruit trees.

comment.author: 69709626@N00
comment._content:
Since I commented on this photo I've found out that my family were itinerant agricultural labour on my father's side. More the horses and harvesting side of things though.

@MyLiliesMyLo - Probably the careful posing, setting and manipulation of shadows were directly influenced by the paintings of the time. There were lots of paintings of people like this as I bet you already know.

comment.author: 64838194@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/staticgirl] 
Thanks for the explanation! Yes, there are lots of those but the ones taken in studios against fake backgrounds are more common, I think. At least, that's what I usually associate with "period" photos.
This is interesting as it's sort of the reverse of artists using photographs as "studies" for paintings. Many Impressionists did this, despite disapproval from those who hadn't embraced photography.
